title: Fortnite Chapter 6 Finale Live Event: Everything You Need To Know About Zero Hour
description: GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.                                          We are fast approaching the end...
body:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.
  
              
          
                We are fast approaching the end to another Fortnite chapter, and that means it's nearly time for a huge live event that will introduce a new era for Epic Games' metaverse. It's Fortnite's biggest party, typically drawing its biggest concurrent player numbers by a wide margin each year. In 2023 it drew more than 11 million players, and 2024's event pulled more than 14 million.And with this year's chapter finale, titled Zero Hour, looking like it's going to rope in every collab Fortnite had over the past 365 days while also picking up old storylines that Fortnite abandoned years ago, this one's looking like quite a doozie.The Fortnite Chapter 6 finale event looks like it'll be quite a spectacle.When is Fortnite's Chapter 6 finale event going down?The live finale event, which will only take place one time, will begin at 11 AM PT / 2 PM ET on Saturday, November 29.You'll be able to join the mode 40 minutes prior to start time, which likely means there will be some sort of pre-show entertainment. Prior to the event at the end of Star Wars season back in June, there was an X-Wing vs TIE Fighter PvP space flight sim for players to enjoy before the main event, so these things can get pretty elaborate.Will Fortnite go offline afterward?Yes. You can expect that Fortnite's servers will go offline for the Chapter 7 update once the event ends. But if all goes well, Fortnite should only be down for about 4-7 hours. Expect Chapter 7 to start in the evening on November 29.Fortnite Chapter 6: Zero Hour live event teaserEpic has offered a cinematic teaser for the event, and it looks like a lot. Check it out.          What can we expect to happen during the Zero Hour event?Based on the teaser, we're going to get some kind of Avengers: Endgame-level confrontation with Chapter 6's ultimate big bad, whose tentacles have made sporadic appearances throughout the chapter. All the past year's Fortnite collabs will team up like it's the end of Ready Player One, and then whatever happens will usher in the Chapter 7 island.We're expecting characters from tons of different IPs that collabed with Fortnite in the past year to show up, with Godzilla x Kong, Star Wars, Halo, K-Pop Demon Hunters, Hatsune Miku, Power Rangers, TMNT, and Superman already being teased. Likewise, at least two upcoming Chapter 7 collabs--Kill Bill and Back to the Future--will also have parts to play.But Zero Hour won't just be about the collabs. The Fortnite original superhero group known as the Seven are almost guaranteed to make their return during this event. None of the members of the Seven have been seen since the end of Chapter 3, so it's been a while.The big question is whether they'll be the same versions of the characters as before. We've already had two different versions of The Paradigm, who were entirely different characters from alternate realities, so we might get to meet a new version of The Foundation not played by Dwayne Johnson. But there have been no rumors either way on that front just yet, so we'll have to wait and see.
                                  
  
    Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

title: Hytale Dev Is Pricing The Game As "Aggressively Low As Possible"
description: GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.                                          Earlier this year, Hytale was...
body:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.
  
              
          
                Earlier this year, Hytale was canceled after spending a decade in development and the studio behind it, Hypixel, was slated to be closed as well. Hypixel co-founder Simon Collins-Laflamme subsequently revived the company and purchased all of the rights for Hytale from Riot Games. Collins-Laflamme also reiterated his commitment to releasing Hypixel in early access. Now, we know how much the game is going to cost.On social media, Hypixel revealed that Hytale will retail for $20. However, there will be more expensive editions with perks including cosmetics that fans can purchase in support of the team. After confirming the price, Collins-Laflamme noted that this decision puts him financially at risk because he's already committed to bankrolling his company and funding the game out of his own pocket."I'm pricing Hytale as aggressively low as possible," wrote Collins-Laflamme on X. "I'm taking on a considerable personal risk after repurchasing the game and getting it ready for early access for a growing team of now 50 talented individuals. I said I was all in, and I am delivering on that promise. The game is unfinished and runs on a build from over four years ago. Charging more didn't feel right. I don't think the game is good yet. My team and I will push hard to make it good, then great. The vision is clear and progress is fast."Collins-Laflamme added that he wants to attract as many players as possible, even during rough economic times. Hypixel has also released a post detailing how far along the modding feature is. The short answer is there's still a lot of work to be done. For now, Hytale doesn't have a release date, but Collins-Laflamme has implied that the game's early-access period will begin relatively soon.
                                  
  
    Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

title: Xbox 360 Turns 20: Here Are Its Top 20 Best-Selling Games In The US
description: By     Blair Marnell   on November 23, 2025 at 7:06AM PST                                GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from...
body:
By 
    Blair Marnell
   on November 23, 2025 at 7:06AM PST    
          
                  GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.
                This weekend marks the 20th anniversary Xbox 360, the second iteration of Microsoft's Xbox consoles. There were a lot of great Xbox 360 games during its run. But looking back, it's staggering to see how many of the top-selling Xbox 360 games were from the Call of Duty franchise.Circana's Mat Piscatella has shared the 20 best-selling Xbox 360 games in the US, and 7 out of the 20 were Call of Duty titles. Six of those games were in the top 10, and four out of the top five as well.Three Halo games and two Gears of War titles made the list, as did perennial best-sellers Minecraft and The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim. Since the acquisitions of Bethesda, Activision, and Mojang Studios, Microsoft now owns the rights to 17 of the titles on this list.Outside of Microsoft's dominion, Rockstar Games had two of the most-acclaimed titles of that generation: Red Dead Redemption and Grand Theft Auto 4. Meanwhile, EA's Battlefield 3 was the publisher's sole title to make the list.Peter Moore--the former Microsoft executive who oversaw Xbox and Xbox 360--recently shared some of the history behind the latter's battle with the PlayStation 3 for the hearts and minds of gamers. The Xbox 360 is one of the biggest hits that Microsoft has ever had in the gaming realm. Although the Xbox 360 store was shut down last year, Microsoft shared an update for the system in June 2025.The complete list of the top 20 best-selling Xbox 360 games in the US is reproduced below. Most of the titles are still available to play on the Xbox Store.20. Gears of War 3Developer: Epic GamesRelease Date: September 20, 201119. Gears of WarDeveloper: Epic GamesRelease Date: November 7, 200618. Red Dead RedemptionDeveloper: Rockstar GamesRelease Date: May 18, 201017. Battlefield 3Developer: DICERelease Date: October 25, 201116. Guitar Hero 3: Legends of RockDeveloper: NeversoftRelease Date: October 28, 200715. MinecraftDeveloper: Mojang StudiosRelease Date: November 18, 201114. Grand Theft Auto 4Developer: Rockstar GamesRelease Date: December 8, 200813. Call of Duty: World at WarDeveloper: TreyarchRelease Date: November 11, 200812. The Elder Scrolls 5: SkyrimDeveloper: Bethesda Game StudiosRelease Date: November 11, 201111. Rock BandDeveloper: HarmonixRelease Date: November 20, 200710. Halo 4Developer: 343 IndustriesRelease Date: November 6, 20129. Call of Duty: GhostsDeveloper: Infinity WardRelease Date: November 13, 20138. Halo: ReachDeveloper: BungieRelease Date: September 14, 20107. Call of Duty 4: Modern WarfareDeveloper: Infinity WardRelease Date: September 14, 20106. Grand Theft Auto 5Developer: Rockstar GamesRelease Date: September 12, 20135. Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2Developer: Infinity WardRelease Date: November 8, 20094. Halo 3Developer: BungieRelease Date: September 25, 20073. Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3Developer: Infinity Ward/Sledgehammer GamesRelease Date: November 8, 20112. Call of Duty: Black OpsDeveloper: TreyarchRelease Date: November 9, 20101. Call of Duty: Black Ops 2Developer: TreyarchRelease Date: November 13, 2012
